scenes.on_screen_action: Full-bleed, high-energy title splash. Fast zoom-in on narrator text: 'Want to build an expert system? Meet CLIPS in 30s.' Drake Hotline Bling meme pops in top-right (two panels). Left panel: blacked-out neural net image; Right panel: clean CLIPS rule text. Quick whoosh sound and cut to next.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Want to build an expert system? Meet CLIPS — rule-based, object-oriented, procedural — in 30 seconds. Let's go!
scenes.on_screen_text:
Want to build an expert system? Meet CLIPS in 30s

Drake Meme:
- Black‑box neural nets — nope
- Readable CLIPS rules — yes

Hook: See one assert make a rule fire — live demo

scenes.on_screen_action: Split-screen: left side shows a neat flowchart Facts → Agenda → Fired Rules; right side shows the Expanding Brain meme with 6 panels animating upward. Tiny animated icons for facts (cards), rules (gears), and agenda (clipboard) fly between panels.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Quick concept blitz: CLIPS is multiparadigm. It uses forward‑chaining — start with facts, match rules, fire actions. Facts are chunks of info; rules are pattern-action pairs.
scenes.on_screen_text:
CLIPS in a flash:
- Multiparadigm: rules, objects, procedures
- Forward‑chaining: facts → match → rules fire
- Facts = relation name + slots

Expanding Brain:
- Prints & ifs — small brain
- Deftemplates + facts — growing brain
- Forward‑chaining rules — galaxy brain

scenes.on_screen_action: Animated timeline: (assert) adds fact card to 'Fact List'; rule icons slide down, match the fact, then a bright orange 'activation' badge sticks to the rule and moves to a clipboard labeled 'Agenda'. Flash label: 'Agenda'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Flow: assert facts, patterns match the facts, matching rules get activated and go on the agenda, then run executes fired rules.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Facts → Agenda → Fired Rules — watch CLIPS do it
Commands:
(assert <fact>)   ; add a fact
(agenda)          ; view active rules
(run)             ; execute rules on the agenda

scenes.on_screen_action: Terminal window animation types in a deftemplate. Code appears with a typewriter effect. Overlay caption: 'Confused by deftemplates? 15s demo'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Deftemplates define the structure of facts — think schema for your facts. Here's a quick template for a person.
scenes.on_screen_text:
(deftemplate person
  (slot name)
  (slot age))

Tip: slots define what values a fact can hold

scenes.on_screen_action: Terminal shows (assert ...) typed and executed. Watch output prints '==> f-1 (person (name John) (age 30)) asserted'. A small 'watch facts' toggle turns on and highlights the output. Surprised Pikachu pops up to the side reacting to the assertion-to-agenda step.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Now assert a fact. Turn on (watch facts) to see CLIPS announce changes — super handy for debugging.
scenes.on_screen_text:
(watch facts)
(assert (person (name John) (age 30)))

Watch output:
==> f-1 (person (name John) (age 30)) asserted

Pro tip: watch facts shows asserts/retracts live

scenes.on_screen_action: Split: left shows a defrule code block; right animates the pattern matching process with variables highlighting (?n binds to 'John'). Use the Drake meme sequence again but with step labels: Step 1 assert, Step 2 match, Step 3 run. Small pointer shows LHS/RHS labels.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Rules have a header, LHS (patterns) and RHS (actions). Variables like ?n capture slot values. Wildcards match values you don't plan to reuse.
scenes.on_screen_text:
(defrule greet-person
  (person (name ?n))   ; LHS: pattern
  =>
  (printout t "Hello " ?n "!" crlf))  ; RHS: action

Notes:
- ?n is a variable
- Use ?$ or ? to wildcard when you don't need the value

scenes.on_screen_action: Terminal: show (agenda) command returning a list with 'greet-person' marked as activated. Animated clipboard shows rule icon being fired when (run) is executed, with a 'PING' sound and a tiny confetti.
scenes.dialogue_vo: When patterns match, the rule is activated — it appears on the agenda. Use (agenda) to inspect. Then (run) fires rules from the agenda.
scenes.on_screen_text:
(agenda)
;; Activations:
0: greet-person (activated)

(run)
;; Output: Hello John!

Flow recap:
assert → agenda → run → rules fire

scenes.on_screen_action: Quick demo of modify and retract in terminal. Show fact‑id f-1 above the prompt. Then show (modify 1 (age 31)) and (retract 1) with watch output. Two Buttons (Sweating Guy) meme flashes comparing 'Spend hours tuning models' vs 'use watch + assert (fast)'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: You can change or remove facts at runtime with modify and retract. This updates matching and the agenda — immediately visible with watch.
scenes.on_screen_text:
(modify 1 (age 31))
;; Watch output: f-1 modified to (age 31)

(retract 1)
;; Watch output: f-1 retracted

Two Buttons:
- Spend hours tuning models
- Or: use watch + assert (fast)
Which do you press?

scenes.on_screen_action: Show deffacts block typed; then show (reset) being executed which clears the environment and auto-asserts the deffacts. Animated broom sweeps the screen then initial facts reappear. Small caption: 'Initial knowledge'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Group initial facts with deffacts so (reset) can reassert them. Reset clears sessions and reinstates your starting knowledge.
scenes.on_screen_text:
(deffacts startup
  "Initial knowledge"
  (person (name John) (age 30))
  (person (name Alice) (age 25)))

(reset)
;; Clears environment, asserts deffacts

Tip: use deffacts for reproducible starts

scenes.on_screen_action: Live mini-demo montage: show (watch facts) on, then type (assert (person (name Bob) (age 40))). Agenda flashes 'greet-person' active. Run, the terminal prints 'Hello Bob!'. Use Surprised Pikachu to react to 'Retract before run -> no firing' quick cut: show retracting fact then running with no output and Pikachu surprised.
scenes.dialogue_vo: See one assert make a rule fire — live. Assert Bob, agenda shows the rule, run — it prints hello. Retract before run? No firing — Surprised Pikachu.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Demo:
(watch facts)
(assert (person (name Bob) (age 40)))
;; ==> f-2 asserted
(agenda)
;; greet-person activated
(run)
;; Hello Bob!

If you (retract 2) before (run) → rule does NOT fire
Surprised Pikachu

scenes.on_screen_action: Rapid meme montage: Distracted Boyfriend centered with labels swapping: 'Me: learning ML pipelines' (boy), 'Turns head for: CLIPS rules' (girlfriend), 'Old fling: heavyweight frameworks' (other). Overlay quick tips popping in corners: variables, wildcards, watch, deffacts. Expanding Brain pops one more time with 'Assert fact → agenda appears → run → automated rule firing'.
scenes.dialogue_vo: Stop juggling heavyweight frameworks — CLIPS gives readable rules, immediate debug via watch, and predictable forward‑chaining. Use variables and wildcards wisely.
scenes.on_screen_text:
Distracted Boyfriend:
- Me: learning ML pipelines
- Turns head for: CLIPS rules
- Old fling: heavyweight frameworks

Quick Tips:
- Use (watch facts)
- (deffacts) + (reset) for reproducible starts
- Variables: ?name
- Wildcards when you don't need the value

scenes.on_screen_action: Final call-to-action panel. Fast scroll of useful commands on the left, follow/subscribe badge on the right, small code snippet at bottom for a snackable summary. End with a playful ping sound and a mini confetti.
scenes.dialogue_vo: That's CLIPS in a minute: deftemplates, facts, rules, agenda, run, reset, watch. Want more demos? Follow for a deep dive — next video: building an expert system from scratch.
scenes.on_screen_text:
CLIPS Cheat Sheet:
- (deftemplate ...)
- (assert ...), (retract <id>), (modify <id> ...)
- (deffacts ...) + (reset)
- (watch facts)
- (agenda) / (run)

See one assert make a rule fire — live demo
Follow for deftemplates next! 

CTA: Follow / Subscribe for more CLIPS tutorials

voice_timing.text: Want to build an expert system? Meet CLIPS — rule-based, object-oriented, procedural — in 30 seconds. Let's go!
Quick concept blitz: CLIPS is multiparadigm. It uses forward‑chaining — start with facts, match rules, fire actions. Facts are chunks of info; rules are pattern-action pairs.
Flow: assert facts, patterns match the facts, matching rules get activated and go on the agenda, then run executes fired rules.
Deftemplates define the structure of facts — think schema for your facts. Here's a quick template for a person.
Now assert a fact. Turn on (watch facts) to see CLIPS announce changes — super handy for debugging.
Rules have a header, LHS (patterns) and RHS (actions). Variables like ?n capture slot values. Wildcards match values you don't plan to reuse.
When patterns match, the rule is activated — it appears on the agenda. Use (agenda) to inspect. Then (run) fires rules from the agenda.
You can change or remove facts at runtime with modify and retract. This updates matching and the agenda — immediately visible with watch.
Group initial facts with deffacts so (reset) can reassert them. Reset clears sessions and reinstates your starting knowledge.
See one assert make a rule fire — live. Assert Bob, agenda shows the rule, run — it prints hello. Retract before run? No firing — Surprised Pikachu.
Stop juggling heavyweight frameworks — CLIPS gives readable rules, immediate debug via watch, and predictable forward‑chaining. Use variables and wildcards wisely.
That's CLIPS in a minute: deftemplates, facts, rules, agenda, run, reset, watch. Want more demos? Follow for a deep dive — next video: building an expert system from scratch.
